Expectation1: Collaborate with other teams to define and design new features
Situation1: Product has scheduled a general brainstorming session next sprint where attendance is optional
Expectation2: Arrive at the polling station during designated voting hours
Situation2: Polls stay open all day and the voter has a light schedule.
Story:
I glanced at my calendar, noticing the optional brainstorming session Product had scheduled for the next sprint. As a software developer, I knew these sessions were where new features were born, and even though attendance wasn’t mandatory, my team always expected me to contribute ideas and insights. I wanted to be there, to show I was invested in the project’s future.

But tomorrow was also election day. As a voter, I felt a strong responsibility to show up at the polling station. The polls would be open all day, and my workload was light, so there was no real excuse to skip voting. Yet, the brainstorming session overlapped with the time I’d planned to vote, and I couldn’t shake the feeling that missing either would mean letting someone down—my team, or my own sense of civic duty.

I sat at my desk, torn between the pull of my professional commitment and the weight of my responsibility as a citizen, feeling the tension build as I tried to figure out how to be present for both.
